1121493373406154752.text: Basically I suppose if you look up to someone, a tag is probably not the best way to gain any relationship. This is something I have discussed with other artists, and the general feeling is that we don't like it. If you want advice, mentorship, etc email is the way to go!

1121489755760250881.text: I am always happy to help via email and message, I do this rather often. But tagging me in a drawing (like literally in the image) leaves me with no context or knowledge of what you want, so I can’t engage.

1121479039791747073.text: I don’t know what the social protocol is here, but please don’t tag me (and many other artists) in drawings you’ve made on Insta? It is hard to manage social media and this is just not a cool way to try to get attention? A comment? I’m not sure what the goal is.

1121114463178878976.text: This is how companies trick new artists into work for exposure, making them do endless free edits, sign away their rights to images, and if nothing else paying them well under what they are worth. New artists are not a cheap alt option, if you want someone's work pay for it.

1121113276257931264.text: These companies are capitalistically predatory and are looking for labor that is cheap. They will work you harder for less pay than someone they consider more seasoned because they think you'll just accept it. They're counting on your naivety and eagerness to work.

1121112493512781824.text: I feel that art is something that people are always trying to cut corners on money-wise. They think there are these tips/tricks to get cheap work, but they're really just attempting to take advantage of newer artists. Many students I've had have work comparable to "big names".

1120106848550416385.text:
Despite this he still finds fun things to try to wake me up at 5 AM like chewing on window locks, trying to eat my hair, or attempting to open my sliding mirror closest. 

He is super happy, healthy, and normally well mannered...he just has an overwhelming need to consume.

1120106283472867328.text: This is usually accompanied by a lot of meowing and start anywhere from an hour before a feeding time to three hours. It is so bad that I had to design my room so that there are no wires accessible to him or paper (he'll rip things off the wall if he can reach it).

1120105945961353216.text: The one thing that Seti does that makes him not a good cat sometimes is that he is food obsessed. The vet says it is just a thing, not a lot we can do. But when he wants to be fed he'll just start chewing on wires and knocking over/pawing at paper for HOURS.

And business info. And general how to function as an artist info!

We as artists succeed and grow stronger the more we share. It isn't like we have an accessible national union (in the US), or even standardized pay. We're all hustling! So, why don't we make that hustle easier?

1116041391589584896.text: Also love how these things have people really reaching and jumping to conclusions. No one is saying you owe it to anyone to sit down and walk them through how you personally craft all of your art. If you wanna make a tutorial or not that is up to you. This is about resources.

1116036096897372160.text: I've had to learn almost everything about my business on my own. Where to produce, how much to make, what sort of stuff to make, and so on. Who knows how much I've lost financially from my blunders? I just straight up refuse at this point to impact others negatively like that.

1116035231151087616.text: This question has literally no impact on how much anyone else would sell, nor how much money they'd make. What happened is even though 1 person did help me, I lacked a full depth of perspectives and did not bring the right amount of stuff. This fully impacted me financially.

1116034889030090752.text: Example: Last year I was going to show at a particular event for the first time. I asked well over 5 other artists how much they normally brought to this event to sell and only 1 person actually answered me in full, the rest dodged that question hard.

1116023758311964675.text: Obviously we can't just sit down and give tons of our time to everyone to help, but simply responding to a genuine question (especially one asked in person) could really shift someone's sales/production/business/etc for the better!!

1116022895304568833.text: Maybe I'm hurting my own work/production/sales/etc, but I don't think I am. I'll tell you exactly how much I have made at previous events, how much to bring, where the best place is to get something made, how to avoid the problems I've faced with creating something, etc.

1116022548121018368.text: I can't believe how much artists still withhold useful information from other artists. Not sharing info at cons, not helping with simple production questions, etc. We talk this big talk about helping one another, but I'm always surprised at how little it happens.

1113642915379552257.text:
My rule of thumb is, generally, imagine if it was a real life interaction. If you wouldn't do/say something like that face to face you shouldn't do it through email. 

You wouldn't ask for help from someone, have them help you, and then silently walk off with no response.

1113641765985067008.text: It is polite, it is setting you up for professional practice skills you'll need with other people, and who knows you may make a lasting connection.

1113641683910938625.text: Just putting out a little life lesson to younger or maybe less experienced artists: if you contact someone asking for help about something in the industry and they take the time to respond to you fully and thoughtfully just take ten seconds and say thank you.

1112023034070626304.text: Since people usually ask: I don't know what breed he is. Vet's best guess is that he is a long/thin asiatic cat breed mix (Thai cat maybe, though one vet did suggest savannah cat ancestry due to his size). Adopt, don't shop. Get an older cat to know their personality!

1112021654186553345.text: He was hyper (and still is), very vocal (he is constantly "talking"), and extremely curious about everything. He is also loyal, very gentle (has never bitten or scratched me, even when he has been in horrible pain), and is the only cat I've ever known to love belly rubs.

1112021026311831553.text: I got Seti after I saw him in an adoption center window. He was lanky and sleepy, they said he was two-ish years old. I thought he was chill and a good pet for a stressed out college student. Turns out they were drugging him to be calm, and he was a much younger five months old.

1110795788655824897.text: Glad others can enjoy these! Clients from hell are no new thing, I’ve got buckets and buckets of stories about artists dealing with the worst clients across all eras and cultures. Maybe one day I’ll share more!

1110709310634381312.text: Last one: He was hired to sculpt the Pietà by Jean de Bilhères. When put up for display Michelangelo overheard people crediting another artist for the work. So he carved MICHAELAGELUS BONAROTUS FLORENTIN FACIEBA (Michelangelo Buonarroti, Florentine, made this) onto her chest.

1110706045142224896.text: Another Michelangelo: When previewing the Last Judgement Biagio da Cesena heavily dissed it. So Michelangelo painted Biagio’s face onto the figure of Minos with donkey ears. The nude figure has a snake biting its penis. Biagio complained to the Pope, who basically laughed at him.

1110704869273268224.text: Clients from Hell Renaissance Edition: When Michelangelo was crafting the David the town mayor Piero Soderini came by and told him the nose was too big. Michelangelo pretended to hammer at the nose, while releasing some marble dust from his hand. Piero said it looked much better.

1110681118360010752.text: Sometimes I just wanna scream for people to take me seriously! I know it is childish, but there is something about everyone treating your profession (that you've worked really hard to have) like it is a cute hobby that makes me wanna scream at the sky.

1110679029567254528.text: But this also happens when I tell people about my work in real life. Lots of pats on the head and being told to "keep it up". It takes until they ask "what I really do for a living" that I have to mention that I make all of my living off of my art and teaching art at a college.

1110678262273851394.text:
Whenever my mom shows off my art to people in her life they're like "oh wow I hope she keeps it up, it is so cute that she likes art".

I'm glad people take what I do seriously.

1110642629639696384.text:
To be fair:
1. by far one of the LEAST weird things that has happened to me on a PDX bus
2. learned some useful tips and tricks for whenever I need to deal with that in the future

1110642026196819968.text: On my bus ride home a man behind me was listening to a "how to cope with grief" audio on his phone at full blast, and it really created a mood on that vehicle.

1109291663589928960.text: I've been real grumpy about art lately, but to turn things around in a more positive way my boss/mentor complimented my latest piece out of no where and I had to keep myself cool during a meeting and not cry about it.

1109212067876073472.text: And no, not a client, not a friend or family member, just a stranger who asked you what you do.

1109211919783620608.text: That fun thing of when someone who has never done your job tells you how to do you how’d they do your job better.

1109112323308806144.text: Also y’all I’m not talking about private commissions (which you should always request payment upfront) I’m talking about clients: big companies, publications, and others who you usually cannot ask to pay upfront.

1108953771063693316.text: Like I've had to coach students on the idea that fighting for your pay as an illustrator is going to happen within your career often and that is gross.

1108922404007378944.text: And this is super common, I don't know a single artist who hasn't had multiple "this client won't pay me" horror story.

1108919948829548545.text:
Whenever you step back from being an artist and realize how often you say "wow I hope this client pays me someday" is such a trip.

Can you imagine what it would be like to be paid without fear within a few weeks of whenever you finish a project? Cause I can't.

1106935976717238277.text: Remember the biggest schools are not always the best schools. The most expensive schools are not always the best schools. Your efforts dictate most of your outcome in education, make what can out of either going to school or not. both are fine options if they're what you need.

1106935421362008064.text: Got out, cleared those debts, and was left to my own devices. Art school was necessary for me as someone with no entry point into this world and no financial backing, but that may not be true for a lot. Evaluate what you need, what you have, and find the best path forward.

1106934884889550848.text: The thing for me with art school was, I came from nothing that could get me into this field. Working class background, no connections, and no language of that world. Would I be here without it? No. But I also got a big scholarship, and went to the least expensive school.

1106605297232048128.text: Asked people on my Insta what sort of enamel pin they want to see me make next. The responses really boiled down to a handful of categories, so I'll ask here which appeals to you the most?

1106534223567945728.text: I’m probably rambling a bit as it is 5 in the morning here, but I’ll end this with as a person of Jewish descent who knows some of that daily fear I am here for my Muslim friends in daily life and online. I’m so sorry, and wish for your safety and health in the coming days.

1106532956061876225.text: You need to confront people in your life who hold hateful viewpoints and you need to hold your governments responsible for their lack of action. This doesn’t happen in a vacuum, people see warning signs and our governments look the other way as hate groups are swelling in size.

1106531230747484160.text: The synagogue shooting here in the US was not long ago. This is happening all too often everywhere to too many minority groups. People keep shrugging and forgetting in a few days, but people who belong to these groups can never forget. They live with the fear daily.

1106530064793952256.text: The pressure of responding to this can’t rest on the shoulders of the Muslim community either, we all need to be vigorously evaluating what we can do to eliminate continued terror being perpetrated against minority groups. We have to refuse this hate at every level.

1106528987784708097.text: I’m still sick over what happened in NZ, my heart goes out to the Muslim community there and all over the world. I’m sick of the bigotry, and the feeling so many have of being unsafe no matter where they go simply because of their religion/identity. Everyone needs to speak up.

1105872777406353408.text: Please have interests outside of your field. It isn't bad, or embarrassing nor does it mean you are not invested in it. I know we've been raised to feel that our lives should only revolve around work, but that just isn't true.

1105872310882320384.text: And on the other end you show a lot of interest in something wildly outside your field and it turns into eye rolls from others. I can't tell you how many times I've voiced my passions for ecology/zoology/environmentalism and have been met with--why do you care/know about that?

1105871639428788225.text: There is something I keep noticing with people my age, and it is a distinct attempt to be indifferent to any interests/passions outside of your chosen work. You'll see a spark of something you know someone likes and they suppress it.

1105697152762732544.text: No matter your skill level focusing on self care and fostering a positive relationship with your creative work matters so much more than anything else I can think of in the long run.

1105601016303517696.text: Improving your creative practice is easy in comparison to teaching yourself how to keep on making despite everything going on externally and internally. The ability to stick with something, has gotten so many people so much farther than just "being good at something naturally".

1105592945145593856.text: I’ve said it once but I’ll say it again persistence is more important within art than talent will ever be.

1105143435537743872.text: And while this is the one that stands out the most, it is by far not the only odd response I've gotten when asking folks to take down reposts. People can really lash out at artists they say they like and respect when you confront them on reposting.

1105138190879383553.text: To this day the weirdest thing someone said to me when I asked them to take down a reposted piece was “every time you (as in me) sell something or advertise yourself you are actually reposting, so stop being a hypocrite”. Love the hoops they jumped though to get to this idea.

1105129163684425728.text: But hey, they're at least making it easier for me to find repostings of my work and get them taken down

1105128419677749248.text: Ultimate weird move: reposting my art with a super weird description, thing you are trying to advertise, or even altering my original work—and tagging me in it.

1099385444205117440.text: Scams have been run throughout history, this is nothing new or special related to the millennial generation. It is just wealth feeding into wealth with new tools, tech, and marketing at the expense of those who have less.

1099382642108071941.text: Then those wealthy people (investors, people who bought into these events, products etc) or even large companies are often framed as the victims, instead of the clear non-investors who have lost their livelihood and even their health.

1099378723684536320.text: Learning more about Fyre Festival, Theranos, and other recent and/or viral instances of fraud I am always amazed at how much the stories told try to focus on the fault being put in "millennial culture" rather than wealthy people believing other wealthy people without question.

1096836288991227904.text: A challenge is one thing, but the artist can choose to take that on or not if you are upfront about what you want. Don't try to sneakily alter their existing style because you couldn't hire/afford XYZ.

1096835977337655296.text: Artists aren't interchangeable. You can't expect a shape based illustrator to take on hyper realistic line art (for the most part) or vice-versa. Why hire someone who has taken years to craft their own unique style and then ask them to work entirely outside of it?

1096835116989444096.text: Hey here is the thing, if you hire an artist with a distinct style then you are hiring them for that style not someone else's. The artist isn't a backup and you can't trick them into rendering someone else's style, either hire them to make their work or don't.

1093640464694046720.text: A reminder. Don't repost work without permission! In doing so you might (though this list is not limited to) take away the original meaning of a piece, deprive the artist of funds/attention they need, or in this case mislead people about what an artist's current body of work is.

1089602888609890304.text: I don't know where your fear, confusion, or reluctance comes from when it comes to speaking up against antisemitism and the violence it creates—but you need to examine it and consider what your silence does.

1089602299129823232.text: People tend to look the other way when I bring up antisemitism, but if any day I could get someone to learn about Jewish history not only during one of the darkest hours of the populations' history (though certainly not the first mass killing by any means) today would be it.

1089601552082362368.text: The wild thing I have learned is that many people don't know how many Jewish people died in the Holocaust. The estimates vary, 5-6 million + though is usually agreed upon. That is 2/3rds of the European Jewish pop. at the time, and 1/3rd of the Jewish pop. worldwide at the time.

1082380941778051072.text: Anyways! I am here for artists who came from little, who’s family are lower/working class, who’s art was not seen as a job option or encouraged. 1078492108921569280.text: Really surprised at how many people have not realized that this isn't about abandoning people who are hurting/busy/not perfect, but having the emotional independence to know when someone just isn't in it for you and being okay with that. This is 100% about learning to let go.

1078331651879358464.text: Be healthy about how you spend your energy, but also try to communicate with the people you’re around. They can’t read your mind, and may not know what you want from them. Also know when to walk away, not everyone wants more friends or will give you what you need and that’s okay.

1078330876683988994.text: I feel like seeing the responses/retweets to this a lot of people are embracing it in a bitter way. I have a small group of friends who are so great, my call for this was to keep myself from wanting those who don’t want me—not abandoning every person who isn’t perfect.

1078179348610334720.text: Listening to coyotes yipping and running through the hills here. Very liminal and hopefully a sign of a good future going into 2019.

1078118588010049536.text: And that being said, mutuals, friends in PDX feel free to reach out if you want. I'm always down to get to know people better.

1078113877336834048.text: My big thing for 2019 is I don't want to chase people anymore. Online, in real life, etc I always feel like I am pursuing bonds that aren't mutually seen to. I want friends who reach back out to me, so next year I'm hunkering down and tending to relationships that want to grow.

1077627902475231234.text: The holidays can be hard for a lot of people whether they’re with their family or alone. This day hasn’t been fun for me for a long time, filled with anxiety, dread, and sadness.

It has been wild, hard, and I loved it.

1069696413586546688.text: And genuine question: historic art forms from all over the world from as far back as 30,000+ years often involve nudity---so @tumblr are you gunna flag the Venus of Willendorf because of her "female presenting nipples"?

1069694128596742144.text: As a space to rep my art Tumblr died for me years ago and I started moving my work and marketing to other social media sites in 2014. But I feel bad for those who still actively use the site as an artistic home base and find this ridiculous "crackdown" to be harmful to creators.

1069693101592047616.text: All of my Mermay drawings were flagged on Tumblr because of their "female presenting nipples", just a normal day in 2018.

1069673994389925888.text: So this week is busy! I'm on some panels for PNCA's Focus Week, Friday night I'll be at the ticketed Crafty Wonderland event, Saturday + Sunday I'll be at the public Crafty Wonderland Holiday Market selling my stuff, and by Monday I hope to have new stuff up on my Etsy!

1069449805796007937.text: I hope that people might take this time during the most well known holiday (though by far not the most important) to educate themselves about these basic things! Almost everyone I meet's knowledge on Judaism and Jewish people as a religion or ethnic groups is lacking.

1069448871539961856.text: I've spent the last month explaining to people around me how antisemitism has existed in the past and how it is growing again today (though it has never left). I've been sad to see how many people didn't even know how many Jews died in the Holocaust, nor other basic info.

1069410967526637568.text: Happy Hanukkah!And a reminder to care for, listen to, and watch out for your Jewish friends and family during these increasingly uncertain and frightening times.

1069394621527089153.text: It's like, I'm continuing a cycle in which I am forced to look "pretty" to be the public face of my work which then hurts myself and other women. But I'm also conning a system I am aware of? There are much smarter people who have mulled this over than me...but damn I'm tired.

1069393297704022016.text: I hate that time when you're preparing to sell at an event and have to consider the usual: the nicer I can get myself to look the more I'll sell stuff--and that's just living in a vacuum of sexism and not knowing whether to play into to get money or to subvert it and suffer.

1069381030488854529.text: I've already edited the cat's anatomy a decent bit since posting this so it is more angular/appealing? So! I'm always fixing things and should wait to post stuff.

1068295548325658626.text: I know in a week I will stare in a mirror and again ask myself if I am any good at this education thing, but I am proud of myself this week. I do try hard, I take time for students in a way I wish many educators had done for me, and I try to make their time engaging.

1068294780436639744.text: I had no one else who could take them. So either I went or no one could go (for free). I also lost my voice from talking to students so much during this time as they'd come in the cafe to discuss things that wanted to talk about with me (problems, class, drawings, whatever).

1068293668182716416.text: Every time I worry about being a bad teacher I will now have to remember this week in which I dragged my sick self to school, walked my students to the MAX, then the zoo, sat in a empty zoo cafe for hours, and then walked them back because I wanted them to be able to go!

1067818024265179136.text: And yes, a repost with a link to the original artist/work is still bad. You are more than capable of reblogging/retweeting/sharing/etc and are choosing to prioritize your platform's attention over that of the likely living artist who needs the views/clicks/etc.

1067817507820630016.text: You can swear up and down all day how you're "helping the artist", but removing links they set up in their post, or even their description of the work is taking away a chance for that artist you "like" to gain followers, attention, money, or even a job.

1067816990411124736.text: Shout out to everyone who reposts art or removes the captions from a post on social media platforms. You're removing the artist's intent and also likely depriving them of audience engagement/money, it is top tier the worst.

1062793025498169344.text: Sometimes I just want to eat or lie down on the floor and not draw. Art requires so much physical and mental effort (and honestly emotional effort too) and it can be very tiring. It is the best job I could ever hope for, but it is difficult and not fun all the time.

1062792464837177346.text: I've talked about it before, but art as a career isn't taken seriously in a lot of ways. Many I meet assume illustrating is 100% fun 100% of the time. I love what I do, I'm passionate about it, but it is work and with all work sometimes it just isn't super fun.

1061669874861191168.text: No excuses for unusually late grading, late responses via email, or lack of involvement with students as it is a part of the job (plus I just personally wanna be there for my students)! But I hope students do know the balance that teachers with multiple jobs are trying to find.

1061669700545916928.text: Additionally for me, I am not paid for my time doing this at home (up to 4-9 hours per project I need to grade). So many educators are putting aside working on paid daily practices to put their energy into grading and other outside of classroom engagement.

1061669549546717184.text: To everyone frustrated with a teacher not grading quickly enough remember that grading each person in my class takes 10-20 mins each to write thoughtful reflections. I usually get my grades to students the week they're due, but I get why now it took so long for my past educators.

1056212822495920128.text: As someone who is not religiously Jewish (I'm nonreligious), but is ethnically mostly part of the Ashkenazi ethnic group (maybe a part of some others) I should not be the only Jewish person someone has met and talked to. AND YET, I continue to be. Expand your connections.

1056210747020046336.text: As a person of Jewish descent I see how this identity is confusing (it's a religion, but also many ethnic groups, some people see it is a race...though not myself). So how do you even talk about it? Here is a hint: reach out to Jewish people, google shit/research, have empathy.

1056209509218045952.text: It isn't fun to talk about, it is actually confusing and messy and upsetting. Jewish identity confuses people and that confusion (I hope is the reason...though I know it isn't the full one) makes a lot of folks not want to talk about antisemitism in this country.

1056208704398192641.text: Remind me again how antisemitism isn't a big deal (a topic that has come up a lot over the past two years for me)?https://twitter.com/W7VOA/status/1056201377586864128 …
